question: Question 1 [latex] \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\left ( \frac{x+\sin x}{x} \right ) [/latex] equals to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\text{Put }  x= \frac{1}{h} & \text{ as } x\rightarrow \infty \: \Rightarrow \: h\rightarrow 0 \\ \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty }\left ( \frac{x+\sin x}{x} \right )&=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\left ( \frac{\frac{1}{h}+\sin \frac{1}{h}}{\frac{1}{h}} \right ) \\   &=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\: 1+\left ( \frac{\sin \frac{1}{h}}{\frac{1}{h}} \right )=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 Given the matrices [latex] J=\begin{bmatrix} 3 &2 &1 \\ 2 &4 &2 \\ 1 &2 &6 \end{bmatrix} [/latex] and [latex] K=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex], the product [latex] K^{T}JK [/latex] is________
solution: [latex]  \begin{aligned}  J&=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1\\ 2 & 4 & 2\\ 1 & 2 & 6 \end{bmatrix} \\    K&=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \\ K^{T}\: JK&=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1\\ 2 & 4 & 2\\ 1 & 2 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \\     &=\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 8 &-1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\\ &=6+16+1=23\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 3 The probability density function of evaporation E on any day during a year in a watershed is given by [latex]f(E)=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{1}{5}&0\leq E\leq 5\; mm/day\\ 0& \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! \! otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The probability that E lies in between 2 and 4 mm/day in a day in the watershed is (in decimal) _____________
solution: [latex]f\left ( E \right )=\begin{cases} \frac{1}{5} & \text{ if } \; 0\leq E\leq mm/day \\ 0 & \; Otherwise \end{cases}[/latex] [latex]P\left ( 2\lt E\lt 4 \right )[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\int_{2}^{4}f\left ( E \right )dE=\int_{2}^{4}\frac{1}{5}dE=\frac{1}{5}\left [ E \right ]_{2}^{4} \\ &=\frac{1}{5}\left ( 4-2 \right )=\frac{2}{5}=0.4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 The sum of Eigen values of the matrix, [M] is where [latex]\left [ M \right ]=\begin{bmatrix} 215 &650 &795\\ 655 &150 &835 \\ 485 &355 &550 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]
solution: Sum of eigen values = trace of matrix =215+150+550 =915

question: Question 5 With reference to the conventional Cartesian (x, y) coordinate system, the vertices of a triangle have the following coordinates: [latex]\left ( x_{1},y_{1} \right )=\left ( 1,0 \right )[/latex]; [latex]\left ( x_{2},y_{2} \right )=\left ( 2,2 \right )[/latex]; and [latex]\left ( x_{3},y_{3} \right )=\left ( 4,3\right )[/latex]. The area of the triangle is equal to
solution: Area of triangle is [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ x_{1}\left ( y_{1}-y_{3} \right )+x_{2}\left ( y_{3}-y_{1} \right )+x_{2}\left ( y_{1}-y_{2} \right ) \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ 1\left ( 2-3 \right )+2\left ( 3-0 \right )+4\left ( 0-2 \right ) \right ] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ -1+6-8 \right ]=\frac{3}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 Match the information given in Group - I with those in Group - II.
Question 7 The possible location of shear centre of the channel section, shown below, is
solution: For no twisting, [latex]\begin{aligned} V \times e &=H \times h\\ \Rightarrow \;\; e&=\frac{Hh}{V}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, possible location of shear center is P.

question: Question 8 The ultimate collapse load (P) in terms of plastic moment [latex]M_{p}[/latex] by kinematic approach for a propped cantilever of length L with P acting at its mid-span as shown in the figure, would be
solution: From principal of virtual work [latex]-M_{P}\theta -M_{P}\theta -M_{P}\theta +W_{u}\frac{L}{2}\theta =0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \; \; W_{u}=\frac{6M_{P}}{L}[/latex]

question: Question 9 While designing, for a steel column of Fe250 grade, a base plate resting on a concrete pedestal of M20 grade, the bearing strength of concrete (in [latex]N/mm^{2}[/latex]) in limit state method of design as per IS:456-2000 is ________________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { Permissible bearing stress } \\ &=0.45 \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{ck}} \\ &=0.45 \times 20=9 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 10 A steel section is subjected to a combination of shear and bending actions. The applied shear force is V and the shear capacity of the section is [latex]V_{s}[/latex]. For such a section, high shear force (as per IS:800-2007) is defined as
Question 11 The degree of static indeterminacy of a rigid jointed frame PQR supported as shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D_{s} &=D_{s_{e}}+D_{s_{i}} \\ &=\left(r_{e}-3\right)+3 C-r_{r} \\ &=(4-3)+3 \times 0-1 \\ &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Since cable is provided, it implies that there is only vertical loading. Hence the structure is stable.

question: Question 12 In a beam of length L, four possible influence line diagrams for shear force at a section located at a distance of [latex]\frac{L}{4}[/latex] from the left end support (marked as P, Q, R and S) are shown below. The correct influence line diagram is
solution: ILD for SF at X-X

question: Question 13 The degree of disturbance of the sample collected by the sampler is expressed by a term called the "area ratio". If the outer diameter and inner diameter of the sampler are [latex]D_{o}[/latex] and [latex]D_{i}[/latex] respectively, the area ratio is given by
Question 14 For a saturated cohesive soil, a triaxial test yields the angle of internal friction ([latex]\phi[/latex] ) as zero. The conducted test is
Question 15 The action of negative skin friction on the pile is to

options.A: increase the ultimate load on the pile
options.B: reduce the allowable load on the pile
options.C: maintain the working load on the pile
options.D: reduce the settlement of the pile

question: Question 16 A long slope is formed in a soil with shear strength parameters: [latex]{c}'=0[/latex]  and [latex]{\phi }'=34^{\circ}[/latex]. A firm stratum lies below the slope and it is assumed that the water table may occasionally rise to the surface, with seepage taking place parallel to the slope. Use [latex]\gamma_{sat}=18 kN/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]\gamma_{w}=10 kN/m^{3}[/latex]. The maximum slope angle (in degrees) to ensure a factor of safety of 1.5, assuming a potential failure surface parallel to the slope, would be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F O S&=\frac{Y_{s u}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{\tan \beta}\\ \Rightarrow \tan \beta&=\left(\frac{\gamma_{\text {sub }}}{\gamma_{\text {sat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{F O S}\right)\\ \Rightarrow \quad \tan \beta&=\frac{\gamma_{\text {sub }}}{\gamma_{\text {aat }}} \cdot \frac{\tan \phi}{1.5}\\ \tan \beta &=\frac{(18-10)}{18 \times 1.5} \times \tan 34^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \beta &=11.30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 An incompressible homogeneous fluid is flowing steadily in a variable diameter pipe having the large and small diameters as 15 cm and 5 cm, respectively. If the velocity at a section at the 15 cm diameter portion of the pipe is 2.5 m/s, the velocity of the fluid (in m/s) at a section falling in 5 cm portion of the pipe is________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\pi}{4}(15)^{2} \times 25 &=\frac{\pi}{4}(5)^{2} \times v \\ \Rightarrow &=2.5 \times 9=22.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 A conventional flow duration curve is a plot between

options.A: Flow and percentage time flow is exceeded
options.B: Duration of flooding and ground level elevation
options.C: Duration of water supply in a city and proportion of area receiving supply exceeding this duration
options.D: Flow rate and duration of time taken to empty a reservoir at that flow rate

question: Question 19 In reservoirs with an uncontrolled spillway, the peak of the plotted outflow hydrograph

options.A: lies outside the plotted inflow hydrograph
options.B: lies on the recession limb of the plotted inflow hydrograph
options.C: lies on the peak of the inflow hydrograph
options.D: is higher than the peak of the plotted inflow hydrograph

question: Question 20 The dimension for kinematic viscosity is
solution: The Sl unit of kinematic viscosity is [latex]\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] Dimension of kinematic viscosity [latex] [\mathrm{v}]=\mathrm{L}^{2} / \mathrm{T} [/latex]

question: Question 21 Some of the nontoxic metals normally found in natural water are
Question 22 The amount of [latex]CO_{2}[/latex] generated (in kg) while completely oxidizing one kg of [latex]CH_{4}[/latex] to the end productsis ____________
solution: [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}+2 \mathrm{O}_{2} \rightarrow \mathrm{CO}_{2}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow\quad[/latex] 16 g of [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}[/latex] when completely oxidized leads to 44 g of [latex]\mathrm{CO}_{2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow\quad [/latex]1 kg of [latex]\mathrm{CH}_{4}[/latex] when completely oxidized leads to [latex] \frac{44}{16} \times 1=2.75 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{CO}_{2}[/latex]

question: Question 23 The minimum value of 15 minute peak hour factor on a section of a road is
solution:
15 min. peak hr factor is used for traffic 
intersection design, [latex]
\begin{array}{c}
\mathrm{PHF}=\frac{(\mathrm{V} / 4)}{V_{15}} \\
V=\text { Peak hourly volume }\left(\mathrm{in} \frac{\mathrm{veh} .}{\mathrm{hr} .}\right)
\end{array}[/latex] [latex]
 V_{15}=[/latex] Maximum 15 minute volume within the peak 
hr. (veh.) Maximum value is 1.0 and minimum value is 0.25 Normal range is 0.7-0.98

question: Question 24 The following statements are related to temperature stresses developed in concrete pavement slabs with free edges (without any restraint): P. The temperature stresses will be zero during both day and night times if the pavement slab is considered weightless Q. The temperature stresses will be compressive at the bottom of the slab during night time if the self-weight of the pavement slab is considered R. The temperature stresses will be compressive at the bottom of the slab during day time if the self -weight of the pavement slab is considered The TRUE statement(s) is(are)
solution: The temperature stress will be tensile at the bottom of the slab during the day time if the self weight of the pavement slab is considered.

question: Question 25 The Reduced Levels (RLs) of the points P and Q are +49.600 m and +51.870 m respectively. Distance PQ is 20 m. The distance (in m from P) at which the +51.000 m contour cuts the line PQ is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \triangle APRS &\sim \triangle P O R, we get\\ \Rightarrow \frac{x}{(51-436)}&=\frac{20}{(5187-43.6)} \\ x&=12.33 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 If the following equation establishes equilibrium in slightly bent position, the mid-span deflection of a member shown in the figure is: [latex]\frac{d^2 y}{ dx^2}+\frac{P}{EI}y=0[/latex] If a is amplitude constant for y, then
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} &=-\frac{P}{E I} x y \\ &=-m^{2} y \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Solution of above differential equation is [latex] \begin{aligned} y&=a \sin m x+b \cos m x \\ \text{at }\quad x&=0, y=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad b&=0 \\ \text{at }\quad x&=L, y=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0&=\sin m L \\ \Rightarrow \quad m L&=n \pi \\ \Rightarrow \quad m&=\frac{n \pi}{L} \\ \therefore \quad y&=a \sin \frac{n \pi x}{L} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A box of weight 100 kN shown in the figure is to be lifted without swinging. If all forces are coplanar, the magnitude and direction ([latex]\theta[/latex]) of the force (F) with respect to x-axis should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{\text {horizontal }} &=0 \\ 90 \mathrm{cos} 30^{\circ} &=40 \mathrm{cos} 45^{\circ}+\mathrm{F} \cos \theta \\ 77.94 &=28.28+\mathrm{F} \cos \theta \\ \text{or}\quad \mathrm{F} \cos \theta &=49.66 \mathrm{kN}&\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma F_{\text {vertical }}&=0\\ 90 \sin 30^{\circ}&+40 \sin 45^{\circ}+F \sin \theta=W \\ 45+28.28+F \sin \theta&=100 \\ \text{or}\quad \quad F \sin \theta&=26.72 \mathrm{kN} &\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Dividing eq. (ii) by eq. (i), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \tan \theta &=\frac{26.72}{49.66}=0.5380 \\ \text{or}\quad\theta &=\tan ^{-1}(0.5380)=28.28^{\circ}\\ \text{Substituting }\theta&=28.28 \text{ in eq. (i), we get}\\ F \cos 28.28^{\circ} &=49.66 \\ \text{or}\quad F &=\frac{49.66}{\cos 28.28^{\circ}}\\ &=\frac{49.66}{0.88}=56.43 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 A particle moves along a curve whose parametric equations are: [latex]x=t^{3}+2t[/latex], [latex]y=-3e^{-2t}[/latex]  and [latex]z=2 \sin (5t)[/latex] , where x, y and z show variations of the distance covered by the particle (in cm)with time t (in s). The magnitude of the acceleration of the particle (in [latex] cm/s^{2}[/latex]) at t = 0 is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x &=t^{3}+2 t \\ y &=-3 e^{-2 t} \\ z &=2 \sin (5 t) \\ \frac{d x}{d t} &=3 e^{2}+2 \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{x} &=\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=6 t \\ \frac{d y}{d t} &=-3 e^{-2} \times(-2)=6 e^{-2 t} \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{y} &=\frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{3}}=-12 e^{-2 t}\\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{d z}{d t} &=2 \times 5 \cos (5 t) \\ &=10 \cos (5 t) \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{z} &=\frac{d^{2} z}{d t^{2}}=-50 \sin 5 t \\ \vec{a} &=a_{x} \hat{i}+a_{y} \hat{j}+a_{z} \hat{k} \\ \vec{a} \text { at } t=0 &=0 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j}+0 \hat{k} \\ \vec{a} &=-12 \hat{j} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow\quad[/latex] Magnitude of acceleration at t=0 [latex] =12 \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 29 A traffic office imposes on an average 5 number of penalties daily on traffic violators. Assume that the number of penalties on different days is independent and follows a Poisson distribution. The probability that there will be less than 4 penalties in a day is ___________
solution: Mean [latex]\; \; \; \; \; \lambda =5[/latex] [latex]P\left ( x \lt 4 \right )=p\left ( x=0 \right )+p\left ( x=1 \right )+p\left ( x=2 \right )+p\left ( x=3 \right )[/latex] [latex]=\frac{e^{-5}s^{0}}{0!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{1}}{1!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{2}}{1!}+\frac{e^{-5}5^{3}}{3!}[/latex] [latex]=e^{-5}\left [ 1+5+\frac{25}{2}+\frac{125}{6} \right ]=e^{-5}\left ( \frac{118}{3} \right )[/latex] [latex]=0.265[/latex]

question: Question 30 Mathematical idealization of a crane has three bars with their vertices arranged as shown in the figure with a load of 80 kN hanging vertically. The coordinates of the vertices are given in parentheses. The force in the member QR, [latex]F_{QR}[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0}+V_{A} &=80 &\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma M_{R} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad 80 \times 3 &=V_{0} \times 2 \\ \therefore\quad V_{O} &=120 \mathrm{KN} \\ \Rightarrow\quad V_{R} &=-40 \mathrm{kN} \quad \text { From eq }(1) \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{1}{4} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \sin \phi &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{17}}, \cos \phi=\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}} \\ \therefore\quad \tan \theta &=\frac{3}{4} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \cos \theta &=\frac{4}{5} \end{aligned}[/latex] Consider joint Q [latex] \begin{aligned} \alpha &=104.03^{\circ}-90^{\circ}=14.03^{\circ} \\ \Sigma F_{y} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \cos \alpha &=+V_{Q}=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \cos 14.03^{\circ} &+120=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} &=-123.6897 \mathrm{kN} \\ \Sigma F_{x} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \sin \alpha &=F_{O R} \\ \therefore\quad F_{O R} &=-29.986 \mathrm{kN} \\ & \simeq 30 \mathrm{kNm}(\text { comp. }) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 For the cantilever beam of span 3 m (shown below), a concentrated load of 20 kN applied at the free end causes a vertical displacement of 2 mm at a section located at a distance of 1 m from the fixed end. If a concentrated vertically downward load of 10 kN is applied at the section located at a distance of 1 m from the fixed end (with no other load on the beam), the maximum vertical displacement in the same beam (in mm) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text { From Betti's law } P_{1} \times \Delta_{12}=P_{2} \times \Delta_{21}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad 10 \times 2=20 \times \Delta_{21}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad \Delta_{21}=1 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 For the truss shown below, the member PQ is short by 3 mm. The magnitude of vertical displacement of joint R (in mm) is _______________
solution: PQ is short by 3 mm We have to find out vertical displacement of joint R in mm, [latex] \Delta_{R}=\Sigma u(\lambda)[/latex] Let in apply unit load at R as shown below [latex] \begin{aligned} u_{P R} \sin \theta &=\frac{1}{2} \\ u_{P Q}+U_{P A} \cos \theta &=0 \\ u_{P O}=-U_{P R} \cos \theta &=-\frac{1}{2 \sin \theta} \cdot \cos \theta \\ u_{P O} &=-\frac{1}{2} \cot \theta \\ &=\frac{-1 \times 4 / 3}{2}=\frac{-2}{3} \\ \Delta_{R} &=u_{P O} \times \lambda_{P O} \\ &=\frac{-2}{3}(-3) \\ &=2 \mathrm{mm}\text{ upwards} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 A rectangular beam of width (b) 230 mm and effective depth (d) 450 mm is reinforced with four bars of 12 mm diameter. The grade of concrete is M20 and grade of steel is Fe500. Given that for M20 grade of concrete the ultimate shear strength, [latex]\tau _{uc} = 0.36 N/mm^{2}[/latex] for steel percentage, p = 0.25, and [latex]\tau _{uc}= 0.48 N/mm^{2}[/latex] for p = 0.50. For a factored shear force of 45 kN, the diameter (in mm) of Fe500 steel two legged stirrups to be used at spacing of 375 mm, should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau_{u c}=& 0.36 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} &[\text{For M20}]\\ & \text { for } \frac{A_{s t}}{b d} \times 100=0.25\\ \tau_{u c}=& 0.48 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} &[\text{For M20}]\\ & \text { for } \frac{A_{s t}}{b d} \times 100=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Factored [latex]S F=45 \mathrm{kN}=V_{u} [/latex] We have to calculate the dia of Fe 500 2-Legged stirrup to be used at a spacing of 325 mm c/c [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{v}&=\frac{V_{u}}{b d}=\frac{45 \times 1000}{230 \times 450}=0.4348 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\\ \therefore \quad \%&\text{tensile steel}\\ &=\frac{4 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(12)^{2}}{230 \times 450} \times 100=0.437 \% \\ \tau_{c} &=0.36+\frac{0.12}{0.25} \times(0.437-0.25) \\ &=0.45 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] since [latex]\tau_{v}-\tau_{c} \lt 0 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Min shear reinforcement is required [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Min shear reinforcement is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{A_{s v}}{b S_{v}} &=\frac{0.4}{0.87 f_{y}} \\ A_{s v} &=\frac{0.4 \times\left(S_{v}\right)(b)}{0.87 f_{y}} \end{aligned}[/latex] since we limit [latex]f_{y}[/latex] to [latex]415 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex] hence, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{s v}=2 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(\phi)^{2} &=\frac{0.4 \times 325 \times 230}{0.87 \times 415} \\ &= 82.814 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \phi &=7.26 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { adopt } \phi&=8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 The tension and shear force (both in kN) in each bolt of the joint, as shown below, respectively are
solution: [latex]\tan \theta =\frac{3}{4}, \; \cos \theta =\frac{4}{5}, \; \sin \theta =\frac{3}{5}[/latex] Tension in each bolt[latex]=\frac{4P_{u}}{5\times 6} = \frac{4\times 250}{5\times 6}=33.33 \; kN[/latex] Shear in each bolt [latex]=\frac{3P_{u}}{5\times 6}=\frac{3\times 250}{5\times 6}=25kN[/latex]

question: Question 35 For a beam of cross -section, width = 230 mm and effective depth = 500 mm, the number of rebars of 12 mm diameter required to satisfy minimum tension reinforcement requirement specified by IS:456-2000 (assuming grade of steel reinforcement as Fe500) is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A_{\text {stmin }}}{b d} &=\frac{0.85}{f_{y}} \\ \text{or},\quad \quad A_{s t} &=\frac{0.85}{500} \times 230 \times 500 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ n &=\frac{A_{s t}}{\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}}=\frac{0.85 \times 230}{\frac{\pi}{4}(12)^{2}} \\ &=1.729=2 \mathrm{bars} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 In a reinforced concrete section, the stress at the extreme fibre in compression is 5.80 MPa. The depth of neutral axis in the section is 58 mm and the grade of concrete is M25. Assuming linear elastic behavior of the concrete, the effective curvature of the section (in per mm) is
solution: Modulus of elasticity of concrete. [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=5000 \sqrt{25} \\ &=25000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{M}{I} &=\frac{\sigma}{y}=\frac{E}{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{R} &=\frac{\sigma}{E y}=\frac{5.8}{E X_{u}} \\ \text { Curvature } &=\frac{5.8}{58 \times 25000} \\ &=4 \times 10^{-6} \text {Per } \mathrm{mm} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \text { Curvature }&=4 \times 10^{-6} \text {per } \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 Group I contains representative load-settlement curves for different modes of bearing capacity failures of sandy soil. Group II enlists the various failure characteristics. Match the load-settlement curves with the corresponding failure characteristics.

Question 38 A given cohesionless soil has [latex]e_{max}=0.85[/latex] and [latex]e_{min}=0.50[/latex]. In the field, the soil is compacted to a mass density of 1800 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]
 at a water content of 8%. Take the mass density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]G_{s}[/latex] as 2.7. The relative density (in %) of the soil is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} e_{max} &=0.85 \\ e_{min} &=0.5 \\ \rho_{\text {field }} &=1800 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\\ &\text{at water content }=8\% \\ \rho_{w}&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ G_{S}&=2.7 \end{aligned}[/latex] Relative density, [latex]\mathrm{I}_{D}=? [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho=\frac{G_{p_{W}}(1+w)}{1+e}&=\frac{2.7 \times 1000(1.08)}{1+e}\\ \Rightarrow\quad 1+e &=\frac{2.7 \times 1000 \times 1.08}{1800} \\ \Rightarrow\quad e &=0.62\\ \Rightarrow\quad I_{D} &=\frac{e_{\max }-e}{e_{\max }-e_{\min }} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{0.85-0.62}{0.85-0.5} \times 100 \\ &=65.714 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The following data are given for the laboratory sample. [latex]{\sigma _{o}}'=175\, \, kPa[/latex]; [latex]e_{o}=1.1[/latex]; [latex]{\sigma _{0}}'+\Delta {\sigma _{o}}'=300\, \, kPa[/latex]; e=0.9 If thickness of the clay specimen is 25 mm, the value of coefficient of volume compressibility is___________[latex]\times 10^{-4}\, m^{2}/kN[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} m_{v} &=\frac{a_{v}}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{\frac{\Delta e}{\Delta \bar{\sigma}}}{1+e_{0}}=\frac{(1.1-0.9)}{125 \times 2.1} \\ &=7.619 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The flow net constructed for the dam is shown in the figure below. Taking the coefficient ofpermeability as [latex]3.8\times 10^{-6}m/s[/latex], the quantity of flow (in [latex]cm^{3}/s[/latex]) under the dam per meter of dam is______________
solution: Quantity of flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\mathrm{kH} \frac{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{f}}}{\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{d}}}\\ \text{Here, } \quad N_{f}&=\text{ No. of flow channels =3 }\\ N_{d}&=\text{ No. of equipotential}\\ \text { drops }=10 \\ \text{Given,}\quad k&=3.8 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{and }\quad H&=6.3 \mathrm{m} \\ Q &=3.8 \times 10^{-6} \times 6.3 \times \frac{3}{10} \times 1 \\ &=7.182 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=7.182 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{6} \mathrm{cm}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} \\ \mathrm{Q} &=7.182 \mathrm{cm}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 A horizontal jet of water with its cross-sectional area of 0.0028 [latex]m^2[/latex] hits a fixed vertical plate with a velocity of 5 m/s. After impact the jet splits symmetrically in a plane parallel to the plane of the plate. The force of impact (in N) of the jet on the plate is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Force on plate } &=\left(\rho_{w} a V\right) \mathrm{V} \\ &=\rho_{w} a V^{2} \\ &=1000 \times 0.0028 \times(5)^{2} \\ &=70 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 A venturimeter, having a diameter of 7.5 cm at the throat and 15 cm at the enlarged end, is installed in a horizontal pipeline of 15 cm diameter. The pipe carries an incompressible fluid at a steady rate of 30 litres per second. The difference of pressure head measured in terms of the moving fluid in between the enlarged and the throat of the venturimeter is observed to be 2.45 m. Taking the acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex], the coefficient of discharge of the venturimeter (correct up to two places of decimal) is___
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=30 \; l / \mathrm{s} \\ \left(\frac{P_{1}}{w}+Z_{1}\right)&-\left(\frac{P_{2}}{w}+Z_{2}\right) =2.45 \mathrm{m}=h \\ g&=9.81 \\ Q&=C_{d} \frac{A_{1} A_{2}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}}} \sqrt{2 g h} \\ C_{d} &=\frac{Q_{1} A_{2}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}} \sqrt{2 g h}}\\ &= \frac{30 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}}{\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}(0.15)^{2} \times(0.075)^{2} }{\sqrt{(0.15)^{2}-(0.075)^{2}}}\times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 2.45}} \\ C_{\mathrm{d}}&=0.95 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A rectangular channel having a bed slope of 0.0001, width 3.0 m and Manning's coefficient 'n' 0.015, carries a discharge of 1.0 [latex]m^3/s[/latex]. Given that the normal depth of flow ranges between 0.76 m and 0.8 m. The minimum width of a throat (in m) that is possible at a given section, while ensuring that the prevailing normal depth is not exceeded along the reach upstream of the contraction, is approximately equal to (assume negligible losses)
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} n=0.015 \\ Q=1 m^{3} / s \end{array}[/latex] Normal depth of flow between 0.76m to 0.8m. If prevailing normal depth of flow is not exceeded, there must not be chocking of the section or there must be just chocking. Thus the width of the section should be such that for the prevailing specific energy there should be critical flow at the contracted section i.e. [latex] \frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=E_{C}=E_{\text {intia }} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{2}\left[\frac{\left(\frac{Q}{B_{\min }}\right)^{2}}{g}\right]^{1 / 3}=E_{\text {initie }}[/latex] Let us now calculate [latex]E_{\text {inital }} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{1}{2} A R^{2 / 3} S_{0}^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1&= \frac{1}{0.015}(3 y)\left(\frac{3 y}{3+2 y}\right)^{2 / 3}(0.0001)^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=0.78 m \\ \Rightarrow \quad E_{\text {initial }}&=y+\frac{q^{2}}{2 g y^{2}} \\ &=0.78+\frac{\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times(0.78)^{2}} \\ &=0.7893 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3}{2}\left[\frac{\left(\frac{Q}{B_{\min }}\right)^{2}}{g}\right]^{1 / 3}&=0.7893 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3}{2} \frac{(1)^{2 / 3}}{g^{1 / 3}\left(B_{\min }\right)^{2 / 3}}&=0.7893 \\ \mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{min}}&=0.836 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Three rigid buckets, shown as in the figures (1), (2) and (3), are of identical heights and base areas. Further, assume that each of these buckets have negligible mass and are full of water. The weights of water in these buckets are denoted as [latex]W_{1},W_{2}, \; and \; W_{3}[/latex] respectively. Also, let the force of water on the base of the bucket be denoted as [latex]F_{1},F_{2}, \;and \; F_{3}[/latex] respectively. The option giving an accurate description of the system physics is
solution: Bucket [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] identical height [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] identical base area [latex] W_{2}>W_{1}>W_{3} [/latex] Force on the base in each case will be equal [latex] to=\gamma_{w} h A [/latex] Hence, [latex]F_{1}=F_{2}=F_{3}[/latex]

options.B: [latex]W_{2} \gt W_{1} \gt W_{3}\; and\;  F_{2} \gt F_{1} \gt F_{3}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 An incompressible fluid is flowing at a steady rate in a horizontal pipe. From a section, the pipe divides into two horizontal parallel pipes of diameters [latex]d_{1}[/latex]
and [latex]d_{2}[/latex] (where [latex]d_{1}=4d_{2}[/latex]) that run for a distance of L each and then again join back to a pipe of the original size. For both the parallel pipes, assume the head loss due to friction only and the Darcy-Weisbach friction factor to be the same. The velocity ratio between the bigger and the smaller branched pipes is

Question 46 16 MLD of water is flowing through a 2.5 km long pipe of diameter 45 cm. The chlorine at the rate of 32 kg/d is applied at the entry of this pipe so that disinfected water is obtained at the exit. There is a proposal to increase the flow through this pipe to 22 MLD from 16 MLD. Assume the dilution coefficient, n = 1. The minimum amount of chlorine (in kg per day) to be applied to achieve the same degree of disinfection for the enhanced flow is
solution: In the disinfection process we have the relationship, [latex]\begin{aligned} tC^{n} &=K \\ \text{where}\; \;t &=\text{time required to kill all organism} \\ \text{c} &=\text{concentration of disinfectant} \\ n &= \text{dilution coefficient}\\ k &=\text{constant} \\ \Rightarrow \; \; t_{1}C_{1}^{n} &=t_{2}C_{2}^{n} \\ \text{in our case}\; n &=1 \\ \Rightarrow \; \; t_{1}C_{1}&=t_{2}C_{2} \\ t_{1} &=\frac{L}{v_{1}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]L= \text{length of pipe}; [/latex] [latex]V_{1}=\text{velocity of flow}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} t_{1} &=\frac{L}{Q_{1}/A} \\ t_{1} &=\frac{L.A}{Q_{1}} \\ C_{1} &=\frac{W_{1}}{Q_{1}}, \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{where } W_{1} &=\text{weight of disinfectant per day}; \\ Q_{1}&=\text{discharge per day} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \; \; \frac{L.A}{Q_{1}}\times \frac{W_{1}}{Q_{1}} &=\frac{L.A}{Q_{2}}\times \frac{W_{2}}{Q_{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \; \; W_{2} &=\frac{Q_{2}^{2}}{Q_{1}^{2}}\times W_{1} \\ &=\left ( \frac{22}{16} \right )^{2}\times 32\; \text{kg/day} \\ &=60.5\; \text{kg/day} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 The potable water is prepared from turbid surface water by adopting the following treatment sequence.

options.A: Turbid surface water [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Coagulation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Flocculation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Sedimentation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Filtration [latex]\rightarrow[/latex]  Disinfection [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Storage & Supply
options.B: Turbid surface water [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Disinfection [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Flocculation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Sedimentation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Filtration [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Coagulation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Storage & Supply
options.C: Turbid surface water [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Filtration [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Sedimentation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Disinfection [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Flocculation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Coagulation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Storage & Supply
options.D: Turbid surface water [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Sedimentation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Flocculation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Coagulation [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Disinfection [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Filtration [latex]\rightarrow[/latex] Storage & Supply

question: Question 48 For a sample of water with the ionic composition shown in the figure below, the carbonate and non-carbonate hardness concentrations (in mg/l as [latex]CaCO_{3}[/latex]), respectivelyare:
solution: 1. Carbonate hardness [latex]=3.5 \times 10^{-3}[/latex] g-eq [if NCH is present sodium alkalinity will be absent i.e. [latex] \mathrm{NaHCO}_{3}[/latex] absent] [latex] =3.5 \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{50 g}{1} as \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] [latex] =175 \mathrm{mg} / l\text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] 2. Non carbonate hardness = total hardness carbonate hardness 3. Total hardness [latex]=5 \times 50 \mathrm{mg} / l\text{ as }\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex] [total hardness is due to [latex]\mathrm{Ca}^{2}+ and \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}[/latex] ] [latex] =250 \mathrm{mg} / l \text{ as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{NCH}=250-175=75 \mathrm{mg} / l \text{ as } \mathrm{CaCO}_{3}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A straight 100 m long raw water gravity main is to carry water from an intake structure to the jack well of a water treatment plant. The required flow through this water main is [latex]0.21 m^{3}/s[/latex]. Allowable velocity through the main is 0.75 m/s. Assume f = 0.01, g=9.81[latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]. The minimum gradient (in cm/100 m length) to be given to this gravity main so that the required amount of water flows without any difficulty is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=0.21 \mathrm{m}^{1} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{Allowable velocily} &=0.75 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ f&=0.01\\ g&=9.81m/s^{2}\\ \frac{\pi d^{2}}{4} &=\frac{0}{v}=\frac{0.21}{0.75}=0.28 m^{2} \\ \Rightarrow\quad d &=0.597 m \\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{ft V^{2}}{2 g d} &=n_{1}=\frac{0.01 \times 100 \times(0.75)^{2}}{2 \times 981 \times 0.597} m \\ &=4.8 \mathrm{cm} \\ &=0.048 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow\quad[/latex] Minimum gradient [latex]=\frac{h_{f}}{l}=\frac{4.8cm}{100m}[/latex] Hence, answor is 4.8

question: Question 50 A traffic survey conducted on a road yields an average daily traffic count of 5000 vehicles. The axle load distribution on the same road is given in the following table: The design period of the road is 15 years, the yearly traffic growth rate is 7.5% and the load safety factor(LSF)1.3. If the vehicle damage factor (VDF) is calculated from the above data, the design traffic (in million standard axle load, MSA) is ____________
solution: Vehicle damage factor [latex] \begin{aligned} &=0.1\left[\frac{18}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.2\left[\frac{14}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.35\left[\frac{10}{8.2}\right]^{4} \\ &\quad+0.15\left[\frac{8}{8.2}\right]^{4}+0.20\left[\frac{6}{8.2}\right]^{4} \\ N_{s}&=\frac{365 A\left((1+r)^{n}-1\right) D F}{r} \\ &=\frac{365 \times 5000\left((1.075)^{15}-1\right) \times 1.3 \times 4.988}{0.075} \\ N_{s}&=309.08 \mathrm{msa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The perception-reaction time for a vehicle travelling at 90 km/h, given the coefficient of longitudinal friction of 0.35 and the stopping sight distance of 170 m (assume g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex] ), is _____________ seconds.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{SSD}&=0.278 \mathrm{vt}_{r}+\frac{(0.278 \mathrm{v})^{2}}{2 \mathrm{gf}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 170&=0.278 \times 90 \times t_{r}+\frac{(0.278 \times 90)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.35} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad t_{r}&=3.1510 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 The speed-density (u-k) relationship on a single lane road with unidirectional flow u= 70-0.7k, where u is in km/hr and k is in veh/km. The capacity of the road (in veh/hr) is________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Capacity } &=\text { Velocity } \times \text { Density } \\ \Rightarrow \quad C &=V \times K \\ &=70 K-0.7 K^{2} \\ \text { Now, } \quad \frac{d C}{d K} &=70-1.4 K=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad K &=50\\ \Rightarrow \quad \text { Capacity, } &=70 \times 50-0.7(50)^{2} \\ &=1750 \mathrm{veh} / \mathrm{hr} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 An isolated three-phase traffic signal is designed by Webster's method. The critical flow ratios for three phases are 0.20, 0.30, and 0.25 respectively, and lost time per phase is 4 seconds. The optimum cycle length (in seconds) is ___________
solution: Sum of the flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} y &=y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3} \\ &=0.2+0.3+0.25=0.75 \end{aligned}[/latex] Total lost time in a cycle [latex]L=4 \times 3=12\text{ sec}. [/latex] Optimum cycle length, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{0} &=\frac{1.5 L+5}{1-y} \\ \frac{1.5 \times 12+5}{1-0.75} &=92 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A levelling is carried out to establish the Reduced Levels (RL) of point R with respect to the Bench Mark (BM) at P. The staff readings taken are given below. If RL of P is +100.000 m, then RL (in m) of R is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H&=A L+B S \\ \text{and }\quad R L&=H I-F S \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore RL\text{ of }R = 101.455m[/latex]

Question 58 Rajan was not happy that Sajan decided to do the project on his own. On observing his unhappiness, Sajan explained to Rajan that he preferred to work independently. Which one of the statements below is logically valid and can be inferred from the above sentences?

options.A: Rajan has decided to work only in a group.
options.B: Rajan and Sajan were formed into a group against their wishes.
options.C: Sajan had decided to give in to Rajan?s request to work with him.
options.D: Rajan had believed that Sajan and he would be working together.

Question 60 A foundry has a fixed daily cost of Rs 50,000 whenever it operates and a variable cost of Rs 800Q, where Q is the daily production in tonnes. What is the cost of production in Rs per tonne for a daily production of 100 tonnes?

Question 62 Anuj, Bhola, Chandan, Dilip, Eswar and Faisal live on different floors in a six-storeyed building (the ground floor is numbered 1, the floor above it 2,and so on). Anuj lives on an even-numbered floor.Bhola does not live on an odd numbered floor. Chandan does not live on any of the floors below Faisal?s floor. Dilip does not live on floor number 2. Eswar does not live on a floor immediately above or immediately below Bhola. Faisal lives three floors above Dilip. Which of the following floor-person combinations is correct? [latex]\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Anuj} & \text{Bhola} & \text{Chandan} & \text{Dilip} & \text{Eswar} & \text{Faisal} \\ \hline (A) & 6 & 2 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 4 \\ \hline (B) & 2 & 6 & 5 & 1 & 3 & 4 \\ \hline (C) & 4 & 2 & 6 & 3 & 1 & 5 \\ \hline (D) & 2 & 4 & 6 & 1 & 3 & 5 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex]

Question 63 The smallest angle of a triangle is equal to two thirds of the smallest angle of a quadrilateral. The ratio between the angles of the quadrilateral is 3:4:5:6. The largest angle of the triangle is twice its smallest angle. What is the sum, in degree, of the second largest angle of the triangle and the largest angle of the quadrilateral?

Question 64 One percent of the people of country X are taller than 6 ft. Two percent of the people of country Y are taller than 6 ft. There are thrice as many people in country X as in country Y. Taking both countries together, what is the percentage of people taller than 6 ft?

Question 65 The monthly rainfall chart based on 50 years of rainfall in Agra is shown in the following figure. Which of the following are true? (k percentile is the value such that k percent of the data fall below that value) br>i.  On average, it rains more in July than in December ii.  Every year, the amount of rainfall in August is more than that in January iii.  July rainfall can be estimated with better confidence than February rainfall iv.  In August, there is at least 500 mm of rainfall
